   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    2010 FIFA World Cup
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
     <span class="mw-redirectedfrom">
      (Redirected from
      <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Cup_2010&amp;redirect=no" title="World Cup 2010">
       World Cup 2010
      </a>
      )
     </span>
    </div>
    <div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">
     Jump to:
     <a href="#mw-head">
      navigation
     </a>

     </a>
    </div>
    <div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en">
     <div class="hatnote">
      "FIFA 2010" redirects here. For the video game, see
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA_10" title="FIFA 10">
       FIFA 10
      </a>
      .
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote">
      This article is about 2010 FIFA World Cup.  For the video game, see
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_South_Africa_(video_game)" title="2010 FIFA World Cup South Africa (video game)">
       2010 FIFA World Cup South Africa (video game)
      </a>
      .  For other uses, see
      <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/2010_World_Cup_(disambiguation)" title="2010 World Cup (disambiguation)">
       2010 World Cup (disambiguation)
      </a>
      .
     </div>

      <tr>
       <td class="noprint" colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
        <div style="float: left;">
         
         <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">
          2006
         </a>

         </a>
         
        </div>

     <p>
      The
      <b>
       2010 FIFA World Cup
      </b>
      was the 19th
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">
       FIFA World Cup
      </a>
      , the world championship for
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_men%27s_national_association_football_teams" title="List of men's national association football teams">
       men's national
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
       association football
      </a>
      teams. It took place in South Africa from 11 June to 11 July 2010. The
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_hosts#2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup hosts">
       bidding process
      </a>
      for hosting the tournament finals was open only to African nations; in 2004, the international football federation,
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">
       FIFA
      </a>
      , selected South Africa over Egypt and Morocco to become the first African nation to host the finals.
     </p>
     <p>
      The matches were played in
      <a href="#Venues">
       10 stadiums
      </a>
      in nine host cities around the country, with the final played at the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soccer_City" title="Soccer City">
       Soccer City
      </a>
      stadium in South Africa's largest city,
      <a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">
       Johannesburg
      </a>
      . Thirty-two teams were selected for participation via a
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification" title="2010 FIFA World Cup qualification">
       worldwide qualification tournament
      </a>
      that began in August 2007. In the
      <a href="#Group_stage">
       first round
      </a>
      of the tournament finals, the teams competed in
      <a href="/wiki/Round-robin_tournament" title="Round-robin tournament">
       round-robin
      </a>
      groups of four teams for points, with the top two teams in each group proceeding. These 16 teams advanced to the
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage" title="2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage">
       knockout stage
      </a>
      , where three rounds of play decided which teams would participate in the
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Final" title="2010 FIFA World Cup Final">
       final
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      In the final,
      <a href="/wiki/Spain_national_football_team" title="Spain national football team">
       Spain
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008" title="UEFA Euro 2008">
       European champions
      </a>
      , defeated third-time finalists the
      <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team" title="Netherlands national football team">
       Netherlands
      </a>
      10
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/After_extra_time" title="After extra time">
       after extra time
      </a>
      , with
      <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Iniesta" title="Andrs Iniesta">
       Andrs Iniesta
      </a>
      's goal in the 116th minute giving Spain their first world title, becoming the eighth nation to win the tournament, and the first European nation to win the tournament outside its home continent. As a result of their win, Spain represented the World in the
      <a href="/wiki/2013_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2013 FIFA Confederations Cup">
       2013 FIFA Confederations Cup
      </a>
      . Host nation
      <a href="/wiki/South_Africa_national_football_team" title="South Africa national football team">
       South Africa
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">
       2006
      </a>
      champions
      <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">
       Italy
      </a>
      and 2006 runners-up
      <a href="/wiki/France_national_football_team" title="France national football team">
       France
      </a>
      were all eliminated in the first round of the tournament. It was the first time that the hosts were eliminated in the first round.
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_national_football_team" title="New Zealand national football team">
       New Zealand
      </a>
      with their three draws were the only undefeated team in the tournament, but were also eliminated in the first round.
     </p>
     <div class="toclimit-3">
      <div class="toc" id="toc">

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Host_selection">
       Host selection
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_hosts#2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup hosts">
       FIFA World Cup hosts  2010 FIFA World Cup
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Africa was chosen as the host for the 2010 World Cup as part of a short-lived policy, abandoned in 2007,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      to rotate the event among football confederations. Five African nations placed bids to host the 2010 World Cup: Egypt, Morocco, South Africa and a joint bid from Libya and Tunisia.
     </p>
     <p>
      Following the decision of the FIFA Executive Committee not to allow co-hosted tournaments, Tunisia withdrew from the bidding process. The committee also decided not to consider Libya's solo bid as it no longer met all the stipulations laid down in the official
      <i>
       List of Requirements
      </i>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      The winning bid was announced by FIFA president
      <a href="/wiki/Sepp_Blatter" title="Sepp Blatter">
       Sepp Blatter
      </a>
      at a media conference on 15 May 2004 in
      <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich" title="Zrich">
       Zrich
      </a>
      ; in the first round of voting South Africa received 14 votes, Morocco received 10 votes and Egypt no votes. South Africa, which had narrowly
      <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup#Host_selection" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">
       failed to win the right to host the 2006 event
      </a>
      , was thus awarded the right to host the tournament.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Having successfully campaigned for South Africa to be granted host status, an emotional
      <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">
       Nelson Mandela
      </a>
      raised the
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy" title="FIFA World Cup Trophy">
       FIFA World Cup Trophy
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-7">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        7
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      During 2006 and 2007, rumours circulated in various news sources that the 2010 World Cup could be moved to another country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harding_8-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-harding-8">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        8
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-9">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        9
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Franz_Beckenbauer" title="Franz Beckenbauer">
       Franz Beckenbauer
      </a>
      , Horst R. Schmidt and, reportedly, some
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">
       FIFA
      </a>
      executives, expressed concern over the planning, organisation, and pace of South Africa's preparations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harding_8-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-harding-8">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        8
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
       <a href="#cite_note-10">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        10
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      FIFA officials repeatedly expressed their confidence in South Africa as host, stating that a contingency plan existed only to cover natural catastrophes, as had been in place at previous FIFA World Cups.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yoong_11-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-yoong-11">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        11
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Bribery_.26_Corruption">
       Bribery &amp; Corruption
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      On 28 May 2015, media covering the
      <a href="/wiki/2015_FIFA_corruption_case" title="2015 FIFA corruption case">
       2015 FIFA corruption case
      </a>
      reported that high-ranking officials from the South African bid committee had secured the right to host the World Cup by paying US $10 million in bribes to then-FIFA Vice President
      <a href="/wiki/Jack_Warner_(football_executive)" title="Jack Warner (football executive)">
       Jack Warner
      </a>
      and to other FIFA Executive Committee members.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
       <a href="#cite_note-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <br/>
      On 4 June 2015, FIFA executive
      <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Blazer" title="Chuck Blazer">
       Chuck Blazer
      </a>
      , having co-operated with the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FBI" title="FBI">
       FBI
      </a>
      and the Swiss authorities, confirmed that he and the other members of FIFA's executive committee were bribed in order to promote the South African 1998 and 2010 World Cups. Blazer stated, "I and others on the Fifa executive committee agreed to accept bribes in conjunction with the selection of South Africa as the host nation for the 2010 World Cup."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
       <a href="#cite_note-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
       <a href="#cite_note-14">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        14
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <br/>
      On 6 June 2015,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph" title="The Daily Telegraph">
        The Daily Telegraph
       </a>
      </i>
      reported that
      <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">
       Morocco
      </a>
      had actually won the vote, but
      <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">
       South Africa
      </a>
      was awarded the tournament instead.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
       <a href="#cite_note-15">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        15
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Qualification">
       Qualification
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification" title="2010 FIFA World Cup qualification">
       2010 FIFA World Cup qualification
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The qualification draw for the 2010 World Cup was held in
      <a href="/wiki/Durban" title="Durban">
       Durban
      </a>
      on 25 November 2007. As the host nation,
      <a href="/wiki/South_Africa_national_football_team" title="South Africa national football team">
       South Africa
      </a>
      qualified automatically for the tournament. As happened in the
      <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">
       previous tournament
      </a>
      , the defending champions were not given an automatic berth, and
      <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">
       Italy
      </a>
      had to participate in qualification. With a pool of entrants comprising 204 of the 208
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_men%27s_national_association_football_teams" title="List of men's national association football teams">
       FIFA national teams
      </a>
      at the time, the 2010 World Cup shares with the
      <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">
       2008 Summer Olympics
      </a>
      the record for most competing nations in a sporting event.
     </p>
     <p>
      Some controversies took place during the qualifications. In the second leg of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/France_vs_Republic_of_Ireland_2010_FIFA_World_Cup_play-off" title="France vs Republic of Ireland 2010 FIFA World Cup play-off">
       play-off between France and the Republic of Ireland
      </a>
      , French captain
      <a href="/wiki/Thierry_Henry" title="Thierry Henry">
       Thierry Henry
      </a>
      , unseen by the referee, handled the ball in the lead up to a late goal, which enabled France to qualify ahead of Ireland, sparking widespread controversy and debate. FIFA rejected a request from the
      <a href="/wiki/Football_Association_of_Ireland" title="Football Association of Ireland">
       Football Association of Ireland
      </a>
      to replay the match,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIFA20Nov09FIFAStatementOnFAIRequest_16-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FIFA20Nov09FIFAStatementOnFAIRequest-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and Ireland later withdrew a request to be included as an unprecedented 33rd World Cup entrant.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UKPA02Dec09BlatterApologisesOverComments_17-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UKPA02Dec09BlatterApologisesOverComments-17">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        17
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IrishTimes02Dec09FAISetsRecordStraight_18-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IrishTimes02Dec09FAISetsRecordStraight-18">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        18
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As a result, FIFA announced a review into the use of technology or extra officials at the highest level, but decided against the widely expected fast-tracking of goal-line referee's assistants for the South African tournament.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UKPA02Dec09FIFARejectExtraRefs_19-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UKPA02Dec09FIFARejectExtraRefs-19">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        19
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2387" data-file-width="3500" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg/220px-Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg/330px-Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg/440px-Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        People watching the 2010 FIFA World Cup in South Africa, with
        <a href="/wiki/Vuvuzela" title="Vuvuzela">
         vuvuzelas
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica_national_football_team" title="Costa Rica national football team">
       Costa Rica
      </a>
      complained over
      <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team" title="Uruguay national football team">
       Uruguay
      </a>
      's winning goal in the
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(inter-confederation_play-offs)#CONCACAF_4th_place_v_CONMEBOL_5th_place" title="2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (inter-confederation play-offs)">
       CONMEBOLCONCACAF playoff
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
       <a href="#cite_note-20">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        20
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      while Egypt and Algeria's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2009_Egypt%E2%80%93Algeria_World_Cup_dispute" title="2009 EgyptAlgeria World Cup dispute">
       November 2009 matches
      </a>
      were surrounded by reports of crowd trouble. On the subject of fair play, FIFA President Sepp Blatter said:
     </p>
     <blockquote class="templatequote">
      <p>
       I appeal to all the players and coaches to observe this fair play. In 2010 we want to prove that football is more than just kicking a ball but has social and cultural value... So we ask the players 'please observe fair play' so they will be an example to the rest of the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCSport02Dec09FIFAToInvestigateHenry_21-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBCSport02Dec09FIFAToInvestigateHenry-21">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         21
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <p>
      Slovakia was making their first appearance as an independent nation but had previously been represented as part of the Czechoslovakia team that had last played in the 1990 tournament. North Korea qualified for the first time since 1966; Honduras and New Zealand were both making their first appearances since 1982, and Algeria were at the finals for the first time since the 1986 competition.
     </p>
     <p>
      Teams that failed to qualify for this tournament included
      <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_national_football_team" title="Saudi Arabia national football team">
       Saudi Arabia
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tunisia_national_football_team" title="Tunisia national football team">
       Tunisia
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team" title="Croatia national football team">
       Croatia
      </a>
      , all of whom had qualified for the previous three finals;
      <a href="/wiki/Sweden_national_football_team" title="Sweden national football team">
       Sweden
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Poland_national_football_team" title="Poland national football team">
       Poland
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Ecuador_national_football_team" title="Ecuador national football team">
       Ecuador
      </a>
      , who had qualified for the previous two editions; and
      <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008" title="UEFA Euro 2008">
       Euro 2008
      </a>
      semi-finalists
      <a href="/wiki/Russia_national_football_team" title="Russia national football team">
       Russia
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Turkey_national_football_team" title="Turkey national football team">
       Turkey
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="List_of_qualified_teams">
       List of qualified teams
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The following 32 teams, shown with final pre-tournament rankings,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
       <a href="#cite_note-22">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        22
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      qualified for the final tournament.
     </p>

           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="800" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/be/Flag_of_England.svg/23px-Flag_of_England.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/be/Flag_of_England.svg/35px-Flag_of_England.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/be/Flag_of_England.svg/46px-Flag_of_England.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">
           England
          </a>
          (8)
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/23px-Flag_of_France.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/35px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/45px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/France_national_football_team" title="France national football team">
           France
          </a>
          (9)
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1000" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/35px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/46px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">
           Germany
          </a>
          (6)
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="600" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Greece.svg/23px-Flag_of_Greece.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Greece.svg/35px-Flag_of_Greece.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Greece.svg/45px-Flag_of_Greece.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Greece_national_football_team" title="Greece national football team">
           Greece
          </a>
          (13)
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1500" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/03/Flag_of_Italy.svg/23px-Flag_of_Italy.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/03/Flag_of_Italy.svg/35px-Flag_of_Italy.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/03/Flag_of_Italy.svg/45px-Flag_of_Italy.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">
           Italy
          </a>
          (5)
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team" title="Netherlands national football team">
           Netherlands
          </a>
          (4)
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="600" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/23px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/35px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/45px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team" title="Portugal national football team">
           Portugal
          </a>
          (3)
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Flag_of_Serbia_%282004-2010%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Serbia_%282004-2010%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Flag_of_Serbia_%282004-2010%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_Serbia_%282004-2010%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Flag_of_Serbia_%282004-2010%29.svg/45px-Flag_of_Serbia_%282004-2010%29.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>

           Serbia
          </a>
          (15)
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Flag_of_Slovakia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Slovakia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Flag_of_Slovakia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Slovakia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Flag_of_Slovakia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Slovakia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Slovakia_national_football_team" title="Slovakia national football team">
           Slovakia
          </a>
          (34)
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Flag_of_Slovenia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Slovenia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Flag_of_Slovenia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Slovenia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Flag_of_Slovenia.svg/46px-Flag_of_Slovenia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Slovenia_national_football_team" title="Slovenia national football team">
           Slovenia
          </a>
          (25)
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="750" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Spain_national_football_team" title="Spain national football team">
           Spain
          </a>
          (2)
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1000" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Switzerland.svg/16px-Flag_of_Switzerland.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Switzerland.svg/24px-Flag_of_Switzerland.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Switzerland.svg/32px-Flag_of_Switzerland.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>

           Switzerland
          </a>
          (24)

        </ul>
       </td>
       <td style="width:25%;text-align:left;vertical-align:top;">
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2010_world_cup_qualification.png">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="625" data-file-width="1425" height="96" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/2010_world_cup_qualification.png/220px-2010_world_cup_qualification.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/2010_world_cup_qualification.png/330px-2010_world_cup_qualification.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/2010_world_cup_qualification.png/440px-2010_world_cup_qualification.png 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2010_world_cup_qualification.png" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           <div class="legend">
            <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #000cff; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
            </span>
            Countries that qualified for 2010 FIFA World Cup
           </div>
           <div class="legend">
            <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ffb400; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
            </span>
            Countries that failed to qualify
           </div>
           <div class="legend">
            <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:black; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
            </span>
            Countries that did not enter
           </div>
           <div class="legend">
            <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ababab; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
            </span>
            Country not a FIFA member
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Preparations">
       Preparations
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      Five new stadiums were built for the tournament, and five of the existing venues were upgraded. Construction costs were expected to be
      <a href="/wiki/South_African_rand" title="South African rand">
       R
      </a>
      8.4billion (just over US$1billion or 950million).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
       <a href="#cite_note-23">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        23
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      South Africa also improved its public transport infrastructure within the host cities, including Johannesburg's
      <a href="/wiki/Gautrain" title="Gautrain">
       Gautrain
      </a>
      and other metro systems, and major road networks were improved.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
       <a href="#cite_note-24">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        24
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In March 2009,
      <a href="/wiki/Danny_Jordaan" title="Danny Jordaan">
       Danny Jordaan
      </a>
      , the president of the 2010 World Cup organising committee, reported that all stadiums for the tournament were on schedule to be completed within six months.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
       <a href="#cite_note-25">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        25
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The country implemented special measures to ensure the safety and security of spectators in accordance with standard FIFA requirements,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
       <a href="#cite_note-26">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        26
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      including a temporary restriction of flight operation in the airspace surrounding the stadiums.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sacaa-45-2_27-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-sacaa-45-2-27">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        27
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      At a ceremony to mark 100 days before the event, FIFA president Sepp Blatter praised the readiness of the country for the event.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
       <a href="#cite_note-28">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        28
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Construction_strike">
       Construction strike
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      On 8 July 2009, 70,000 construction workers
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
       <a href="#cite_note-29">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        29
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      who were working on the new stadiums walked off their jobs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
       <a href="#cite_note-30">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        30
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The majority of the workers receive
      <a href="/wiki/South_African_rand" title="South African rand">
       R
      </a>
      2500 per month (about
      <a href="/wiki/Pound_sterling" title="Pound sterling">
       
      </a>
      192, 224 or US$313), but the unions alleged that some workers were grossly underpaid. A spokesperson for the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Union_of_Mineworkers_(South_Africa)" title="National Union of Mineworkers (South Africa)">
       National Union of Mineworkers
      </a>
      said to the
      <a href="/wiki/South_African_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="South African Broadcasting Corporation">
       SABC
      </a>
      that the "no work no pay" strike would go on until FIFA assessed penalties on the organisers. Other unions threatened to strike into 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
       <a href="#cite_note-31">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        31
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
       <a href="#cite_note-32">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        32
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The strike was swiftly resolved and workers were back at work within a week of it starting. There were no further strikes and all stadiums and construction projects were completed in time for the kick off.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
       <a href="#cite_note-33">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        33
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Prize_money">
       Prize money
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      The total prize money on offer for the tournament was confirmed by FIFA as US$420million (including payments of US$40million to domestic clubs), a 60 percent increase on the 2006 tournament.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIFA03Dec09RecordPrizeMoney_34-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FIFA03Dec09RecordPrizeMoney-34">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        34
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Before the tournament, each of the 32 entrants received US$1million for preparation costs. Once at the tournament, the prize money was distributed as follows:
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIFA03Dec09RecordPrizeMoney_34-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-FIFA03Dec09RecordPrizeMoney-34">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        34
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <ul>
      <li>
       US$8million  To each team eliminated at the
       <a href="#Group_stage">
        group stage
       </a>
       (16 teams) ($8.65 million in 2015 US dollars
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inflation-US_35-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-inflation-US-35">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         35
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       )
      </li>
      <li>
       US$9million  To each team eliminated in the
       <a href="#Round_of_16">
        round of 16
       </a>
       (8 teams) ($9.73 million in 2015 US dollars
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inflation-US_35-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-inflation-US-35">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         35
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       )
      </li>
      <li>
       US$14million  To each team eliminated in the
       <a href="#Quarter-finals">
        quarter-finals
       </a>
       (4 teams) ($15.14 million in 2015 US dollars
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inflation-US_35-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-inflation-US-35">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         35
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       )
      </li>
      <li>
       US$18million 
       <a href="#Third-place_play-off">
        Fourth placed team
       </a>
       ($19.47 million in 2015 US dollars
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inflation-US_35-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-inflation-US-35">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         35
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       )
      </li>
      <li>
       US$20million 
       <a href="#Third-place_play-off">
        Third placed team
       </a>
       ($21.63 million in 2015 US dollars
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inflation-US_35-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-inflation-US-35">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         35
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       )
      </li>
      <li>
       US$24million 
       <a href="#Final">
        Runner up
       </a>
       ($25.96 million in 2015 US dollars
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inflation-US_35-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-inflation-US-35">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         35
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       )
      </li>
      <li>
       US$30million 
       <a href="#Final">
        Winner
       </a>
       ($32.44 million in 2015 US dollars
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inflation-US_35-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-inflation-US-35">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         35
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       )
      </li>
     </ul>
     <p>
      In a first for the World Cup, FIFA made payments to the domestic clubs of the players representing their national teams at the tournament. This saw a total of US$40million paid to domestic clubs. This was the result of an agreement reached in 2008 between FIFA and European clubs to disband the
      <a href="/wiki/G-14" title="G-14">
       G-14
      </a>
      group and drop their claims for compensation dating back to 2005 over the financial cost of injuries sustained to their players while on international duty, such as that from Belgian club
      <a href="/wiki/R._Charleroi_S.C." title="R. Charleroi S.C.">
       Charleroi S.C.
      </a>
      for injury to Morocco's
      <a href="/wiki/Abdelmajid_Oulmers" title="Abdelmajid Oulmers">
       Abdelmajid Oulmers
      </a>
      in a friendly game in 2004, and from English club
      <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_United_F.C." title="Newcastle United F.C.">
       Newcastle United
      </a>
      for an injury to England's
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Owen" title="Michael Owen">
       Michael Owen
      </a>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">
       2006 World Cup
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Journal1Mar2007_36-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Journal1Mar2007-36">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        36
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC06Sep2005G14FightFifa_37-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BBC06Sep2005G14FightFifa-37">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        37
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC15Feb2008G14Disbanded_38-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BBC15Feb2008G14Disbanded-38">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        38
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Venues">
       Venues
      </span>
     </h2>

        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GPS_eXchange_Format" title="GPS eXchange Format">

        </a>
       </td>

      <tr>
       <td>
        <a class="external text" href="http://maps.google.com/maps?q=http%3A%2F%2Fmicroform.at%2Fgeo%2Fhttp%3A%2F%2Fen.wikipedia.org%2Fwiki%2F2010_FIFA_World_Cup" rel="nofollow">
         Map all microformatted coordinates
        </a>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td>
        <a class="external text" href="http://microform.at/?type=hcard-rdf&amp;url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" rel="nofollow">
         Place data as RDF
        </a>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      In 2005, the organisers released a provisional list of 13 venues to be used for the World Cup:
      <a href="/wiki/Bloemfontein" title="Bloemfontein">
       Bloemfontein
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Cape_Town" title="Cape Town">
       Cape Town
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Durban" title="Durban">
       Durban
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">
       Johannesburg
      </a>
      (two venues),
      <a href="/wiki/Kimberley,_Northern_Cape" title="Kimberley, Northern Cape">
       Kimberley
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Klerksdorp" title="Klerksdorp">
       Klerksdorp
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Nelspruit" title="Nelspruit">
       Nelspruit
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Orkney,_North_West" title="Orkney, North West">
       Orkney
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Polokwane" title="Polokwane">
       Polokwane
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Port_Elizabeth" title="Port Elizabeth">
       Port Elizabeth
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Pretoria" title="Pretoria">
       Pretoria
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Rustenburg" title="Rustenburg">
       Rustenburg
      </a>
      . This was narrowed down to the ten venues
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
       <a href="#cite_note-39">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        39
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      that were officially announced by FIFA on 17 March 2006.
     </p>
     <p>
      The altitude of several venues affected the motion of the ball
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
       <a href="#cite_note-40">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        40
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and player performance,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
       <a href="#cite_note-41">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        41
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
       <a href="#cite_note-42">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        42
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      although FIFA's medical chief downplayed this consideration.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
       <a href="#cite_note-43">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        43
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Six of the ten venues were over 1200m above sea level, with the two Johannesburg stadiums (Soccer City and Ellis Park) the highest at approximately 1750m.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-racingpost_44-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-racingpost-44">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        44
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SoccerAmerica_45-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SoccerAmerica-45">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        45
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The stadiums in order of altitude are:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soccer_City" title="Soccer City">
       Soccer City
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Ellis_Park_Stadium" title="Ellis Park Stadium">
       Ellis Park Stadium
      </a>
      , 1753m;
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Bafokeng_Stadium" title="Royal Bafokeng Stadium">
       Royal Bafokeng Stadium
      </a>
      , 1500m;
      <a href="/wiki/Free_State_Stadium" title="Free State Stadium">
       Free State Stadium
      </a>
      , 1400m;
      <a href="/wiki/Peter_Mokaba_Stadium" title="Peter Mokaba Stadium">
       Peter Mokaba Stadium
      </a>
      , 1310m;
      <a href="/wiki/Loftus_Versfeld_Stadium" title="Loftus Versfeld Stadium">
       Loftus Versfeld Stadium
      </a>
      , 1214m;
      <a href="/wiki/Mbombela_Stadium" title="Mbombela Stadium">
       Mbombela Stadium
      </a>
      , 660m;
      <a href="/wiki/Cape_Town_Stadium" title="Cape Town Stadium">
       Cape Town Stadium
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Moses_Mabhida_Stadium" title="Moses Mabhida Stadium">
       Moses Mabhida Stadium
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela_Bay_Stadium" title="Nelson Mandela Bay Stadium">
       Nelson Mandela Bay Stadium
      </a>
      near sea level.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-racingpost_44-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-racingpost-44">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        44
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SoccerAmerica_45-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-SoccerAmerica-45">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        45
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <center>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>

            <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:South_Africa_location_map.svg" title="2010 FIFA World Cup is located in South Africa">

             </div>

               </a>
              </span>
             </div>
            </div>
            <div style="position:absolute;top:54.607%;left:59.354%">
             <div style="position:absolute;left:-4px;top:-4px;line-height:0">
              <img alt="Bloemfontein" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="8" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Bloemfontein" width="8"/>
             </div>

              <span style="padding:1px;float:right">
               <a href="/wiki/Bloemfontein" title="Bloemfontein">
                Bloemfontein
               </a>
              </span>
             </div>
            </div>
            <div style="position:absolute;top:15.856%;left:78.307%">
             <div style="position:absolute;left:-4px;top:-4px;line-height:0">
              <img alt="Polokwane" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="8" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Polokwane" width="8"/>
             </div>

                Polokwane
               </a>

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Team_base_camps">
       Team base camps
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The base camps are used by 32 national squads to stay and train before and during the World Cup tournament. In February 2010, FIFA announced the base camps for each participating team.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
       <a href="#cite_note-51">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        51
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Fifteen teams were in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gauteng_Province" title="Gauteng Province">
       Gauteng Province
      </a>
      , while six teams were based in
      <a href="/wiki/KwaZulu-Natal" title="KwaZulu-Natal">
       KwaZulu-Natal
      </a>
      , four in the
      <a href="/wiki/Western_Cape" title="Western Cape">
       Western Cape
      </a>
      , three in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_West_Province" title="North West Province">
       North West Province
      </a>
      and one each in
      <a href="/wiki/Mpumalanga" title="Mpumalanga">
       Mpumalanga
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Cape" title="Eastern Cape">
       Eastern Cape
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Cape" title="Northern Cape">
       Northern Cape
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
       <a href="#cite_note-52">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        52
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="multicol" role="presentation" style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 0; border: 0; background:transparent; width:100%;">

          </a>
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/23px-Flag_of_France.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/35px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/45px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/France_national_football_team" title="France national football team">
           France
          </a>
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Japan_national_football_team" title="Japan national football team">
           Japan
          </a>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Final_draw">
       Final draw
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_seeding" title="2010 FIFA World Cup seeding">
       2010 FIFA World Cup seeding
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The FIFA Organising Committee approved the procedure for the final draw on 2 December 2009. The seeding was based on the October 2009 FIFA World Ranking and seven squads joined hosts South Africa as seeded teams for the final draw. No two teams from the same confederation were to be drawn in the same group, except allowing a maximum of two European teams in a group.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-draw_53-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-draw-53">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        53
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable" style="width:98%;">
      <tr>
       <th width="25%">
        <b>
         Pot 1
        </b>
        (Host &amp;
        <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Rankings" title="FIFA World Rankings">
         Top seven
        </a>
        )
       </th>
       <th width="25%">
        <b>
         Pot 2
        </b>
        (
        <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(AFC)" title="2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)">
         Asia
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(CONCACAF)" title="2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)">
         North America
        </a>
        &amp;
        <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(OFC)" title="2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (OFC)">
         Oceania
        </a>
        )
       </th>
       <th width="25%">
        <b>
         Pot 3
        </b>
        (
        <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(CAF)" title="2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)">
         Africa
        </a>
        &amp;
        <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(CONMEBOL)" title="2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)">
         South America
        </a>
        )
       </th>
       <th width="25%">
        <b>
         Pot 4
        </b>
        (
        <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(UEFA)" title="2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)">
         Europe
        </a>
        )
       </th>
      </tr>

         <br/>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="1350" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Serbia_national_football_team" title="Serbia national football team">
          Serbia
         </a>
         <br/>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Flag_of_Slovakia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Slovakia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Flag_of_Slovakia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Slovakia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Flag_of_Slovakia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Slovakia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Slovakia_national_football_team" title="Slovakia national football team">
          Slovakia
         </a>
         <br/>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Flag_of_Slovenia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Slovenia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Flag_of_Slovenia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Slovenia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Flag_of_Slovenia.svg/46px-Flag_of_Slovenia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Slovenia_national_football_team" title="Slovenia national football team">
          Slovenia
         </a>
         <br/>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1000" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Switzerland.svg/16px-Flag_of_Switzerland.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Switzerland.svg/24px-Flag_of_Switzerland.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Switzerland.svg/32px-Flag_of_Switzerland.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Switzerland_national_football_team" title="Switzerland national football team">
          Switzerland
         </a>
        </p>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      The group draw was staged in
      <a href="/wiki/Cape_Town" title="Cape Town">
       Cape Town
      </a>
      , South Africa, on 4 December 2009 at the
      <a href="/wiki/Cape_Town_International_Convention_Centre" title="Cape Town International Convention Centre">
       Cape Town International Convention Centre
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
       <a href="#cite_note-54">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        54
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The ceremony was presented by South African actress
      <a href="/wiki/Charlize_Theron" title="Charlize Theron">
       Charlize Theron
      </a>
      , assisted by FIFA Secretary General
      <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_Valcke" title="Jrme Valcke">
       Jrme Valcke
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
       <a href="#cite_note-55">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        55
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The balls were drawn by
      <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">
       English
      </a>
      football star
      <a href="/wiki/David_Beckham" title="David Beckham">
       David Beckham
      </a>
      and African sporting figures
      <a href="/wiki/Haile_Gebrselassie" title="Haile Gebrselassie">
       Haile Gebrselassie
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/John_Smit" title="John Smit">
       John Smit
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Makhaya_Ntini" title="Makhaya Ntini">
       Makhaya Ntini
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Matthew_Booth_(soccer)" title="Matthew Booth (soccer)">
       Matthew Booth
      </a>
      and Simphiwe Dludlu.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
       <a href="#cite_note-56">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        56
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Referees">
       Referees
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_officials" title="2010 FIFA World Cup officials">
       2010 FIFA World Cup officials
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies#Refereeing" title="2010 FIFA World Cup controversies">
       2010 FIFA World Cup controversies  Refereeing
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      FIFA's Referees' Committee selected 29
      <a href="/wiki/Referee_(association_football)" title="Referee (association football)">
       referees
      </a>
      through its Refereeing Assistance Programme to officiate at the World Cup: four from the
      <a href="/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation" title="Asian Football Confederation">
       AFC
      </a>
      , three from the
      <a href="/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football" title="Confederation of African Football">
       CAF
      </a>
      , six from
      <a href="/wiki/CONMEBOL" title="CONMEBOL">
       CONMEBOL
      </a>
      , four from
      <a href="/wiki/CONCACAF" title="CONCACAF">
       CONCACAF
      </a>
      , two from the
      <a href="/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation" title="Oceania Football Confederation">
       OFC
      </a>
      and ten from
      <a href="/wiki/UEFA" title="UEFA">
       UEFA
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
       <a href="#cite_note-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      English referee Howard Webb was chosen to referee the final, making him the first person to referee both the
      <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League" title="UEFA Champions League">
       UEFA Champions League
      </a>
      final and the World Cup final in the same year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
       <a href="#cite_note-58">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        58
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Squads">
       Squads
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2340" data-file-width="3500" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg/220px-FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg/330px-FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg/440px-FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The Brazilian and North Korean teams before their group stage match
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote">
      For more details on this topic, see
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_squads" title="2010 FIFA World Cup squads">
       2010 FIFA World Cup squads
      </a>
      .
     </div>
     <p>
      As with the
      <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup_squads" title="2006 FIFA World Cup squads">
       2006 tournament
      </a>
      , each team's squad for the 2010 World Cup consisted of 23 players. Each participating national association had to confirm their final 23-player
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_squads" title="2010 FIFA World Cup squads">
       squad
      </a>
      by 1 June 2010. Teams were permitted to make late replacements in the event of serious injury, at any time up to 24 hours before their first game.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
       <a href="#cite_note-59">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        59
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Of the 736 players participating in the tournament, over half played their club football in five European domestic leagues; those in England (117 players), Germany (84), Italy (80), Spain (59) and France (46).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
       <a href="#cite_note-60">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        60
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The English, German and Italian squads were made up of entirely home based players, while only Nigeria had no players from clubs in their own league. In all, players from 52 national leagues entered the tournament.
      <a href="/wiki/FC_Barcelona" title="FC Barcelona">
       FC Barcelona
      </a>
      of Spain was the club contributing the most players to the tournament, with 13 players of their side travelling, 7 with the Spanish team, while another 7 clubs contributed 10 players or more.
     </p>
     <p>
      In another first for South Africa 2010, one squad included three siblings.
      <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Palacios" title="Jerry Palacios">
       Jerry
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Johnny_Palacios" title="Johnny Palacios">
       Johnny
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Wilson_Palacios" title="Wilson Palacios">
       Wilson Palacios
      </a>
      made history thanks to their inclusion in Honduras's 23-man list.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers_61-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers-61">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        61
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Unusually, the game between
      <a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">
       Germany
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Ghana_national_football_team" title="Ghana national football team">
       Ghana
      </a>
      had two brothers playing for opposite nations, with
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerome_Boateng" title="Jerome Boateng">
       Jerome Boateng
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Kevin-Prince_Boateng" title="Kevin-Prince Boateng">
       Kevin-Prince Boateng
      </a>
      playing respectively.
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Group_stage">
       Group stage
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      The first round, or group stage, saw the thirty-two teams divided into eight groups of four teams. Each group was a
      <a href="/wiki/Round-robin_tournament" title="Round-robin tournament">
       round-robin
      </a>
      of six games, where each team played one match against each of the other teams in the same group. Teams were awarded three points for a win, one point for a draw and none for a defeat. The teams finishing first and second in each group qualified for the Round of 16.
     </p>
     <p>
      The South American teams performed strongly, with all five advancing to the knockout stages (four as group winners), and four made the quarter-finals (the only team from South America to not make it this far was
      <a href="/wiki/Chile_national_football_team" title="Chile national football team">
       Chile
      </a>
      , who lost to
      <a href="/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team" title="Brazil national football team">
       Brazil
      </a>
      ); but only Uruguay advanced to the semi-finals.
     </p>
     <p>
      The overall performance of African teams on the first occasion that the continent hosted the event was judged disappointing by observers such as Cameroon great
      <a href="/wiki/Roger_Milla" title="Roger Milla">
       Roger Milla
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
       <a href="#cite_note-62">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        62
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Of the six African nations only three won any matches (Ghana, South Africa and Ivory Coast), and only one (Ghana) progressed out of the first round. South Africa became the first host in FIFA World Cup history to not make it out of the group stage, finishing third in Group A behind
      <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team" title="Uruguay national football team">
       Uruguay
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team" title="Mexico national football team">
       Mexico
      </a>
      , but ahead of
      <a href="/wiki/France_national_football_team" title="France national football team">
       France
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Only six out of 13
      <a href="/wiki/UEFA" title="UEFA">
       UEFA
      </a>
      teams progressed to the last 16, a record low since the round of 16 was adopted in 1986. Still, the final was played by two European teams.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers_61-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers-61">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        61
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Both of the finalists from the preceding tournament, France and Italy, were eliminated in the initial stage of the competition, the first time this has happened at a World Cup. It was also only the third time the reigning champions were eliminated in the first round of the finals (after Brazil in 1966 and France in 2002).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
       <a href="#cite_note-63">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        63
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Surprisingly,
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_national_football_team" title="New Zealand national football team">
       New Zealand
      </a>
      , a team projected by many to not attain a point in Group F, ended the tournament as the only undefeated team after drawing their three group matches, but they finished behind
      <a href="/wiki/Paraguay_national_football_team" title="Paraguay national football team">
       Paraguay
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Slovakia_national_football_team" title="Slovakia national football team">
       Slovakia
      </a>
      and were eliminated.
     </p>
     <p>
      <span id="Tie-breaking_criteria">
      </span>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:602px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2010_world_cup.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="625" data-file-width="1425" height="263" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/2010_world_cup.png/600px-2010_world_cup.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/2010_world_cup.png/900px-2010_world_cup.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/2010_world_cup.png/1200px-2010_world_cup.png 2x" width="600"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2010_world_cup.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <table class="multicol" role="presentation" style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 0; border: 0; background:transparent; width:100%;">
         <tr>
          <td style="width:25%;text-align:left;vertical-align:top;">
           <div class="legend">
            <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #2b42a3; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
            </span>
            Champion
           </div>
           <div class="legend">
            <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #34c0be; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
            </span>
            Runner-up
           </div>
          </td>
          <td style="width:25%;text-align:left;vertical-align:top;">
           <div class="legend">
            <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #269c5a; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
            </span>
            Third place
           </div>
           <div class="legend">
            <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #81c846; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
            </span>
            Fourth place
           </div>
          </td>
          <td style="width:25%;text-align:left;vertical-align:top;">
           <div class="legend">
            <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #e4e454; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
            </span>
            Quarter-finals
           </div>
           <div class="legend">
            <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #f4d4ac; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
            </span>
            Round of 16
           </div>
          </td>
          <td style="width:25%;text-align:left;vertical-align:top;">
           <div class="legend">
            <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #b94954; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
            </span>
            Group stage
           </div>
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <dl>
      <dt>
       Tie-breaking criteria
      </dt>
     </dl>
     <p>
      Teams were ranked on the following criteria:
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010_FIFA_World_Cup_South_Africa_-_Regulations_64-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-2010_FIFA_World_Cup_South_Africa_-_Regulations-64">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        64
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <dl>
      <dd>
       1. Greater number of points in all group matches
      </dd>
      <dd>
       2. Goal difference in all group matches
      </dd>
      <dd>
       3. Greater number of goals scored in all group matches
      </dd>
      <dd>
       4. Greatest number of points in matches between tied teams
      </dd>
      <dd>
       5. Goal difference in matches between tied teams
      </dd>
      <dd>
       6. Greatest number of goals scored in matches between tied teams
      </dd>
      <dd>
       7. Drawing of lots by the FIFA Organising Committee
      </dd>
     </dl>
     <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center">
      <tr>
       <th colspan="2">
        Key to colours in group tables
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td style="background:#cfc; width:20px">
       </td>
       <td align="left">
        Teams that advanced to the
        <a href="#Round_of_16">
         round of 16
        </a>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>

      <span class="mw-headline" id="Group_A">

      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">

      </a>

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Group_F">
       Group F
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_F" title="2010 FIFA World Cup Group F">
       2010 FIFA World Cup Group F
      </a>
     </div>
     <table>
      <tr>
       <td>
        <table class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; font-size: 90%;">
         <tr>
          <th width="165">
           <div style="text-align:center; position:relative; white-space:nowrap;">
            Team
            <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="position:absolute; right:0; top:0; margin:0 5px;">

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Knockout_stage">
       Knockout stage
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage" title="2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage">
       2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      <i>
       All times listed are
       <a href="/wiki/South_African_Standard_Time" title="South African Standard Time">
        South African Standard Time
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UTC%2B02" title="UTC+02">
        UTC+02
       </a>
       )
      </i>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Single-elimination_tournament" title="Single-elimination tournament">
       knockout stage
      </a>
      comprised the 16 teams that advanced from the group stage of the tournament. There were four rounds of matches, with each round eliminating half of the teams entering that round. The successive rounds were the round of 16, quarter-finals, semi-finals, and the final. There was also a play-off to decide third and fourth place. For each game in the knockout stage, any draw at 90 minutes was followed by thirty minutes of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Extra_time" title="Extra time">
       extra time
      </a>
      ; if scores were still level, there was a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Penalty_shootout_(association_football)" title="Penalty shootout (association football)">
       penalty shootout
      </a>
      to determine who progressed to the next round.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-regulations_65-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-regulations-65">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        65
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 90%; margin:1em 2em 1em 1em;">
      <tr>
       <td height="5">
       </td>

        </b>
        (
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Penalty_shootout_(association_football)" title="Penalty shootout (association football)">
         pen.
        </a>
        )
       </td>
       <td rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;border:1px solid #aaa;background-color:#f9f9f9;">
        <b>

        </b>
       </td>
      </tr>
