     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Round_of_16">
       Round of 16
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In this round, each group winner (A-H) was paired against the runner-up from another group.
     </p>
     <ul>
      <li>
       South American teams again performed strongly in the round of 16, with four teams advancing to the quarter-finals including
       <a href="/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team" title="Brazil national football team">
        Brazil
       </a>
       who defeated fellow South American team
       <a href="/wiki/Chile_national_football_team" title="Chile national football team">
        Chile
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       England's 41 loss to Germany was their biggest ever margin of defeat at a World Cup finals.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
        <a href="#cite_note-66">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         66
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         67
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       It was also the first time that a World Cup finals match between these two traditional rivals had a decisive result in regulation time, their
       <a href="/wiki/England%E2%80%93Germany_football_rivalry" title="EnglandGermany football rivalry">
        four previous meetings
       </a>
       all being tied at 90 minutes, with two settled in extra time and one in a penalty shootout.
      </li>
      <li>
       Ghana defeated the United States to become the third African team to reach the last eight (after
       <a href="/wiki/Cameroon_national_football_team" title="Cameroon national football team">
        Cameroon
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1990 FIFA World Cup">
        1990
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Senegal_national_football_team" title="Senegal national football team">
        Senegal
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2002 FIFA World Cup">
        2002
       </a>
       ), and the only African team to have achieved both a top 8 finish and a separate top 16 finish (in 2006).
      </li>
      <li>
       Paraguay and Ghana reached the quarter-finals for the first time.
      </li>
     </ul>
     <p>
      The round was marked by some
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_2010_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies" title="List of 2010 FIFA World Cup controversies">
       controversial referees' decisions
      </a>
      , including:
     </p>
     <ul>
      <li>
       A disallowed goal by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Germany_v_England_(2010)" title="Germany v England (2010)">
        England in their 41 loss against Germany
       </a>
       , where the shot by
       <a href="/wiki/Frank_Lampard" title="Frank Lampard">
        Frank Lampard
       </a>
       was seen to cross the goal line when shown on television broadcast replays.
      </li>
      <li>
       An allowed goal by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentina_v_Mexico_(2010)" title="Argentina v Mexico (2010)">
        Argentina in their 31 win over Mexico
       </a>
       , where Argentine striker
       <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Tevez" title="Carlos Tevez">
        Carlos Tevez
       </a>
       was seen to be offside when shown on television broadcast replays, which were shown inside the stadium shortly after the incident.
      </li>
     </ul>
     <p>
      FIFA President
      <a href="/wiki/Sepp_Blatter" title="Sepp Blatter">
       Sepp Blatter
      </a>
      took the unusual step of apologising to England and Mexico for the decisions that went against them, saying: "Yesterday I spoke to the two federations directly concerned by referees' mistakes [...] I apologised to England and Mexico. The English said thank you and accepted that you can win some and you lose some and the Mexicans bowed their head and accepted it."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blatter_apology_68-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Blatter_apology-68">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        68
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Blatter also promised to re-open the discussion regarding devices which monitor possible goals and make that information immediately available to match officials, saying: "We will naturally take on board the discussion on technology and have the first opportunity in July at the business meeting."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blatter_apology_68-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Blatter_apology-68">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        68
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Blatter's call came less than four months after FIFA general secretary
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerome_Valcke" title="Jerome Valcke">
       Jerome Valcke
      </a>
      said the door was closed on
      <a href="/wiki/Goal-line_technology" title="Goal-line technology">
       goal-line technology
      </a>
      and video replays after a vote by the
      <a href="/wiki/International_Football_Association_Board" title="International Football Association Board">
       IFAB
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blatter_apology_68-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Blatter_apology-68">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        68
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="vevent" style="width: 100%; background-color: transparent; clear:both">
      <p>

     <div class="vevent" style="width: 100%; background-color: transparent; clear:both">
      <p>
       <span class="summary" style="display: none;">
        <a href="/wiki/Spain_national_football_team" title="Spain national football team">
         Spain
        </a>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="750" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        v
        <span class="flagicon">

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Quarter-finals">
       Quarter-finals
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The three quarter-finals between European and South American teams all resulted in wins for Europeans. Germany had a 40 victory over Argentina, and the Netherlands came from behind to beat Brazil 21, handing the Brazilians their first loss in a World Cup match held outside Europe (other than in a penalty shootout) since
      <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_v_Brazil_(1950_FIFA_World_Cup)" title="Uruguay v Brazil (1950 FIFA World Cup)">
       1950
      </a>
      when Uruguay won the decisive match 21.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
       <a href="#cite_note-69">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        69
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Spain reached the final four for the first time since 1950 after a 10 win over Paraguay. Uruguay, the only South American team to reach the semi-finals, overcame Ghana in a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Penalty_shootout_(football)" title="Penalty shootout (football)">
       penalty shoot-out
      </a>
      after a 11 draw in which Ghana missed a penalty at the end of extra time.
     </p>
     <div class="vevent" style="width: 100%; background-color: transparent; clear:both">
      <p>
       <span class="summary" style="display: none;">
        <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team" title="Netherlands national football team">
         Netherlands
        </a>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        v
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="504" data-file-width="720" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/22px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/33px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/43px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 2x" width="22"/>

      <div style="clear:both;">

     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Semi-finals">
       Semi-finals
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The Netherlands qualified for the final for the third time with a 32 win over Uruguay. Spain reached their first ever final with a 10 victory over Germany. As a result, it was the first World Cup final not to feature at least one of Brazil, Italy, Germany or Argentina.
     </p>
     <div class="vevent" style="width: 100%; background-color: transparent; clear:both">
      <p>
       <span class="summary" style="display: none;">
        <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team" title="Uruguay national football team">
         Uruguay
        </a>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Uruguay.svg/23px-Flag_of_Uruguay.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Uruguay.svg/35px-Flag_of_Uruguay.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Uruguay.svg/45px-Flag_of_Uruguay.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        v
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>

         Netherlands
        </a>

         </a>
         <img alt="Goal" data-file-height="313" data-file-width="313" height="13" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Soccerball_shade.svg/13px-Soccerball_shade.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Soccerball_shade.svg/20px-Soccerball_shade.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Soccerball_shade.svg/26px-Soccerball_shade.svg.png 2x" title="Goal" width="13"/>
         <span style="font-size: 10px; vertical-align: middle;">
          73'
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Third_place_play-off">
       Third place play-off
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Germany defeated Uruguay 32 to secure third place. Germany holds the record for most third-place finishes in the World Cup (4), while Uruguay holds the record for most fourth-place finishes (3).
     </p>
     <div class="vevent" style="width: 100%; background-color: transparent; clear:both">
      <p>
       <span class="summary" style="display: none;">
        <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team" title="Uruguay national football team">
         Uruguay
        </a>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Uruguay.svg/23px-Flag_of_Uruguay.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Uruguay.svg/35px-Flag_of_Uruguay.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Uruguay.svg/45px-Flag_of_Uruguay.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        v
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1000" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/35px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/46px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">
         Germany
        </a>
       </span>
      </p>

          <br/>

          <br/>

      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Final">
       Final
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Final" title="2010 FIFA World Cup Final">
       2010 FIFA World Cup Final
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The final was held on 11 July 2010 at
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soccer_City" title="Soccer City">
       Soccer City
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">
       Johannesburg
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Spain_national_football_team" title="Spain national football team">
       Spain
      </a>
      defeated the
      <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team" title="Netherlands national football team">
       Netherlands
      </a>
      10, with an extra time goal from
      <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Iniesta" title="Andrs Iniesta">
       Andrs Iniesta
      </a>
      . Iniesta scored the latest winning goal in a FIFA World Cup final (116').
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIFA_71-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FIFA-71">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        71
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The win gave Spain their first World Cup title, becoming the eighth team to win it. This made them the first new winner without home advantage since Brazil in 1958,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
       <a href="#cite_note-72">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        72
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the first team to win the tournament after having lost their opening game.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers_61-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers-61">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        61
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A large number of fouls were committed in the final match. Referee
      <a href="/wiki/Howard_Webb" title="Howard Webb">
       Howard Webb
      </a>
      handed out 14 yellow cards, more than doubling the previous record for this fixture, set when Argentina and West Germany shared six cards in 1986,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers_61-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers-61">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        61
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/John_Heitinga" title="John Heitinga">
       John Heitinga
      </a>
      of the Netherlands was sent off for receiving a second yellow card. The Netherlands had chances to score, most notably in the 60th minute when Arjen Robben was released by
      <a href="/wiki/Wesley_Sneijder" title="Wesley Sneijder">
       Wesley Sneijder
      </a>
      to be one-on-one with Spain's goalkeeper
      <a href="/wiki/Iker_Casillas" title="Iker Casillas">
       Iker Casillas
      </a>
      , only for Casillas to save the shot with an outstretched leg. For Spain,
      <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Ramos" title="Sergio Ramos">
       Sergio Ramos
      </a>
      missed a free header from a corner kick when he was unmarked.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_report_73-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-bbc_report-73">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        73
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Iniesta finally broke the deadlock in extra time, scoring a volleyed shot from a pass by
      <a href="/wiki/Cesc_F%C3%A0bregas" title="Cesc Fbregas">
       Cesc Fbregas
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
       <a href="#cite_note-74">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        74
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      This result marked the first time that two different teams from the same continent had won successive World Cups (following Italy in 2006), and saw Europe reaching 10 World Cup titles, surpassing South America's nine titles. Spain became the first team since West Germany in 1974 to win the World Cup as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UEFA_European_Football_Championship" title="UEFA European Football Championship">
       European champions
      </a>
      . The result also marked the first time that a European nation had won a World Cup Finals that was not hosted on European soil.
     </p>
     <p>
      A closing ceremony was held before the final, featuring singer
      <a href="/wiki/Shakira" title="Shakira">
       Shakira
      </a>
      . Afterwards, the former South African President
      <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">
       Nelson Mandela
      </a>
      made a brief appearance on the pitch, wheeled in by a motorcart.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
       <a href="#cite_note-75">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        75
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="vevent" style="width: 100%; background-color: transparent; clear:both">
      <p>
       <span class="summary" style="display: none;">
        <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team" title="Netherlands national football team">
         Netherlands
        </a>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        v
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="750" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Spain_national_football_team" title="Spain national football team">
         Spain
        </a>
       </span>
      </p>
      <table style="float:left; width:15%; table-layout:fixed">
       <tr>
        <td>
         <div style="text-align:right">
          11 July 2010
          <br/>
          20:30
          <br/>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <table style="float:left; width:61%; table-layout:fixed; text-align:center">
       <tr style="vertical-align:top">
        <th class="vcard attendee" style="width:39%; text-align:right">
         <span class="fn org">
          <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team" title="Netherlands national football team">
           Netherlands
          </a>
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
         </span>
        </th>
        <th style="width:22%; text-align:center">
         <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Final" title="2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage">
          01
         </a>
         (
         <a href="/wiki/Overtime_(sports)#Association_football" title="Overtime (sports)">
          a.e.t.
         </a>
         )
        </th>
        <th class="vcard attendee" style="width:39%; text-align:left">
         <span class="fn org">
          <span class="flagicon">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="750" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Spain_national_football_team" title="Spain national football team">
           Spain
          </a>
         </span>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr style="vertical-align:top;font-size:85%">
        <td style="text-align:right">
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center">
         <a class="external text" href="http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/worldcup/southafrica2010/matches/round=249721/match=300061509/report.html" rel="nofollow">
          Report
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left">
         <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Iniesta" title="Andrs Iniesta">
          Iniesta
         </a>
         <img alt="Goal" data-file-height="313" data-file-width="313" height="13" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Soccerball_shade.svg/13px-Soccerball_shade.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Soccerball_shade.svg/20px-Soccerball_shade.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Soccerball_shade.svg/26px-Soccerball_shade.svg.png 2x" title="Goal" width="13"/>
         <span style="font-size: 10px; vertical-align: middle;">
          116'
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <table style="float:left; width:24%; table-layout:fixed">
       <tr>
        <td>
         <div style="font-size: 85%">
          <span class="location">
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soccer_City" title="Soccer City">
            Soccer City
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">
            Johannesburg
           </a>
          </span>
          <br/>
          Attendance: 84,490
          <br/>
          Referee:
          <a href="/wiki/Howard_Webb" title="Howard Webb">
           Howard Webb
          </a>
          (
          <a href="/wiki/The_Football_Association" title="The Football Association">
           England
          </a>
          )
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-referees_63-64_70-1">
           <a href="#cite_note-referees_63-64-70">
            <span>
             [
            </span>
            70
            <span>
             ]
            </span>
           </a>
          </sup>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Statistics">
       Statistics
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_statistics" title="2010 FIFA World Cup statistics">
       2010 FIFA World Cup statistics
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Goalscorers">
       Goalscorers
      </span>
     </h3>
     <dl>
      <dd>
       <i>
        For the full list of goalscorers, see
        <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_statistics#Goalscorers" title="2010 FIFA World Cup statistics">
         2010 FIFA World Cup goalscorers
        </a>
       </i>
      </dd>
     </dl>
     <p>
      South African winger
      <a href="/wiki/Siphiwe_Tshabalala" title="Siphiwe Tshabalala">
       Siphiwe Tshabalala
      </a>
      was the first player to score a goal in the competition, in their
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A#South_Africa_vs_Mexico" title="2010 FIFA World Cup Group A">
       11 draw against Mexico
      </a>
      , the opening game of the tournament. Danish defender
      <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Agger" title="Daniel Agger">
       Daniel Agger
      </a>
      was credited with the first
      <a href="/wiki/Own_goal" title="Own goal">
       own goal
      </a>
      of the tournament, in his side's
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_E#Netherlands_vs_Denmark" title="2010 FIFA World Cup Group E">
       20 loss to the Netherlands
      </a>
      . Argentine striker
      <a href="/wiki/Gonzalo_Higua%C3%ADn" title="Gonzalo Higuan">
       Gonzalo Higuan
      </a>
      was the only player to score a
      <a href="/wiki/Hat-trick" title="Hat-trick">
       hat-trick
      </a>
      in the tournament, in Argentina's
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_B#Argentina_vs_South_Korea" title="2010 FIFA World Cup Group B">
       41 win over South Korea
      </a>
      . It was the 49th
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_FIFA_World_Cup_hat-tricks" title="List of FIFA World Cup hat-tricks">
       World Cup hat-trick
      </a>
      in the history of the tournament.
     </p>
     <p>
      Spain set a new record for the fewest goals scored by a World Cup-winning team, with eight.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_report_73-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-bbc_report-73">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        73
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The previous record low was 11, set by Brazil in
      <a href="/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1994 FIFA World Cup">
       1994
      </a>
      , England in
      <a href="/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1966 FIFA World Cup">
       1966
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_report_73-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-bbc_report-73">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        73
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and Italy in
      <a href="/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1938 FIFA World Cup">
       1938
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
       <a href="#cite_note-76">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        76
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Spain had the fewest goalscorers for a champion as well (three  Villa with five goals, Iniesta with two and Puyol with one).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers_61-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers-61">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        61
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      They also had the fewest goals conceded for a champion (2), equal with Italy (2006) and France (1998). Spain's victory marked the first time that a team won the World Cup without conceding a goal in the knockout stage.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIFA_71-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-FIFA-71">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        71
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The four top scorers in the tournament had five goals each. All of the four top scorers also came from the teams that finished in the top four, Spain, the Netherlands, Germany, and Uruguay. The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Cup_Golden_Boot" title="World Cup Golden Boot">
       Golden Boot
      </a>
      went to
      <a href="/wiki/Thomas_M%C3%BCller" title="Thomas Mller">
       Thomas Mller
      </a>
      of Germany who had three
      <a href="/wiki/Assist_(football)" title="Assist (football)">
       assists
      </a>
      , compared to one for the three others. The Silver Boot went to
      <a href="/wiki/David_Villa" title="David Villa">
       David Villa
      </a>
      of Spain, who played a total of 635 minutes, and the Bronze Boot to
      <a href="/wiki/Wesley_Sneijder" title="Wesley Sneijder">
       Wesley Sneijder
      </a>
      of the Netherlands, who played 652 minutes.
      <a href="/wiki/Diego_Forl%C3%A1n" title="Diego Forln">
       Diego Forln
      </a>
      of Uruguay had five goals and one assist in 654 minutes. A further three players scored four goals.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
       <a href="#cite_note-77">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        77
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Only 145 goals were scored at South Africa 2010, the lowest of any FIFA World Cup since the tournament switched to a 64-game format. This continued a downward trend since the first 64-game finals were held 12 years earlier, with 171 goals at France 1998, 161 at Korea/Japan 2002 and 147 at Germany 2006.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers_61-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-South_Africa_2010_in_numbers-61">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        61
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Discipline">
       Discipline
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_disciplinary_record" title="2010 FIFA World Cup disciplinary record">
       2010 FIFA World Cup disciplinary record
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      28 players were suspended after being shown two consecutive yellow cards (13 players), a single red card (8 players), or a yellow card followed by a red card (7 players).
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">
       Awards
      </span>
     </h3>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Golden_Ball_(FIFA)" title="Golden Ball (FIFA)">
        Golden Ball
       </a>
       :
       <span class="flagicon">
        <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">
         <img alt="Uruguay" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Uruguay.svg/23px-Flag_of_Uruguay.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Uruguay.svg/35px-Flag_of_Uruguay.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Uruguay.svg/45px-Flag_of_Uruguay.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </a>
       </span>
       <a href="/wiki/Diego_Forl%C3%A1n" title="Diego Forln">
        Diego Forln
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team" title="Uruguay national football team">

       </a>
       )
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-golden_ball_2-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-golden_ball-2">
         <span>

         </span>
         2
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>

         </span>

       </sup>
      </li>

       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yashin_Award" title="Yashin Award">

       </a>
       :
       <span class="flagicon">

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="All-Star_Team">
       All-Star Team
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The All-Star Team was decided by an online public vote, in which people were invited to select a team (in a
      <a href="/wiki/Formation_(association_football)#4.E2.80.934.E2.80.932" title="Formation (association football)">
       442 formation
      </a>
      ) and best coach. Voting was open until 23:59 on 11 July 2010,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
       <a href="#cite_note-80">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        80
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      with entrants going into a draw to win a prize.
     </p>
     <p>
      Six of the eleven players came from the Spanish team, as did the coach. The remainder of the team comprised two players from Germany, and one each from Brazil, the Netherlands and Uruguay.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
       <a href="#cite_note-81">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        81
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
       <a href="#cite_note-82">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        82
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Goalkeeper_(association_football)" title="Goalkeeper (association football)">
        Goalkeeper
       </a>
       :
       <span class="flagicon">
        <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
         <img alt="Spain" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="750" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </a>
       </span>
       <a href="/wiki/Iker_Casillas" title="Iker Casillas">
        Iker Casillas
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Spain_national_football_team" title="Spain national football team">
        Spain
       </a>
       )
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Defender_(association_football)" title="Defender (association football)">
        Defenders
       </a>
       :
       <span class="flagicon">
        <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
         <img alt="Spain" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="750" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>

       </span>

       </a>

        Spain
       </a>

       <span class="flagicon">
        <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">
         <img alt="Brazil" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="504" data-file-width="720" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/22px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/33px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/43px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 2x" width="22"/>

       </span>

       </a>

       <a href="/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team" title="Brazil national football team">

       </a>
       ),
       <span class="flagicon">
        <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">
         <img alt="Germany" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1000" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/35px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/46px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>

      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Midfielder" title="Midfielder">

       </a>

       <span class="flagicon">
        <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
         <img alt="Spain" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="750" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </a>

        Andrs Iniesta
       </a>

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Post-tournament_team_ranking">
       Post-tournament team ranking
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Shortly after the final, FIFA issued a final ranking of every team in the tournament. The ranking was based on progress in the competition, overall results and quality of the opposition. All 32 teams are ranked based on criteria which have been used by
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">
       FIFA
      </a>
      . The final ranking was as follows:
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
       <a href="#cite_note-83">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        83
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%; text-align: center;">
      <tr>
       <th width="25">
        <abbr title="Final Ranking">

        </abbr>
       </th>

        <a href="/wiki/Honduras_national_football_team" title="Honduras national football team">
         Honduras
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_H" title="2010 FIFA World Cup Group H">
         H
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>

       </td>
       <td>

       </td>
       <td>

       </td>

       </td>

      </tr>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Symbols">
       Symbols
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2010_World_Cup_Autographed_by_the_entire_Spanish_National_Team_that_won_the_2010_World_Cup.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4608" data-file-width="3456" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/2010_World_Cup_Autographed_by_the_entire_Spanish_National_Team_that_won_the_2010_World_Cup.JPG/220px-2010_World_Cup_Autographed_by_the_entire_Spanish_National_Team_that_won_the_2010_World_Cup.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/2010_World_Cup_Autographed_by_the_entire_Spanish_National_Team_that_won_the_2010_World_Cup.JPG/330px-2010_World_Cup_Autographed_by_the_entire_Spanish_National_Team_that_won_the_2010_World_Cup.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/2010_World_Cup_Autographed_by_the_entire_Spanish_National_Team_that_won_the_2010_World_Cup.JPG/440px-2010_World_Cup_Autographed_by_the_entire_Spanish_National_Team_that_won_the_2010_World_Cup.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2010_World_Cup_Autographed_by_the_entire_Spanish_National_Team_that_won_the_2010_World_Cup.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Spain_national_football_team" title="Spain national football team">
         Spain
        </a>
        shirt, autographed by members of the World Cup-winning squad, on display in Madrid
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Mascot">
       Mascot
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Zakumi" title="Zakumi">
       Zakumi
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_mascot" title="FIFA World Cup mascot">
       official mascot
      </a>
      for the 2010 World Cup was
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Zakumi" title="Zakumi">
        Zakumi
       </a>
      </i>
      , an
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anthropomorphic" title="Anthropomorphic">
       anthropomorphised
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/African_leopard" title="African leopard">
       African leopard
      </a>
      with green hair, presented on 22 September 2008. His name came from "ZA" (the
      <a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-2" title="ISO 3166-1 alpha-2">
       international abbreviation
      </a>
      for South Africa) and the term
      <i>
       kumi
      </i>
      , which means "ten" in various
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_languages" title="African languages">
       African languages
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
       <a href="#cite_note-84">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        84
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The mascot's colours reflected those of the host nation's playing strip  yellow and green.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Official_song">
       Official song
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_official_songs" title="FIFA World Cup official songs">
       FIFA World Cup official songs
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The official song of the 2010 World Cup "
      <a href="/wiki/Waka_Waka_(This_Time_for_Africa)" title="Waka Waka (This Time for Africa)">
       Waka Waka
      </a>
      " was performed by the
      <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">
       Colombian
      </a>
      singer
      <a href="/wiki/Shakira" title="Shakira">
       Shakira
      </a>
      and the band
      <a href="/wiki/Freshlyground" title="Freshlyground">
       Freshlyground
      </a>
      from South Africa, and is sung in both English and Spanish.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
       <a href="#cite_note-85">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        85
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The song is based on a traditional African soldiers' song, "
      <a href="/wiki/Zamina_mina_(Zangalewa)" title="Zamina mina (Zangalewa)">
       Zangalewa
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
       <a href="#cite_note-86">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        86
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Shakira and Freshlyground performed the song at the pre-tournament concert in
      <a href="/wiki/Soweto" title="Soweto">
       Soweto
      </a>
      on 10 June. It was also sung at the
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_opening_ceremony" title="2010 FIFA World Cup opening ceremony">
       opening ceremony
      </a>
      on 11 June and at the closing ceremony on 11 July. The official anthem of the 2010 World Cup was "
      <a href="/wiki/Sign_of_a_Victory" title="Sign of a Victory">
       Sign of a Victory
      </a>
      " by
      <a href="/wiki/R._Kelly" title="R. Kelly">
       R. Kelly
      </a>
      with the Soweto Spiritual Singers, which was also performed at the opening ceremony.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Match_ball">
       Match ball
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Adidas_Jabulani" title="Adidas Jabulani">
       Adidas Jabulani
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The match
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Association_football_(ball)" title="Association football (ball)">
       ball
      </a>
      for the 2010 World Cup, manufactured by
      <a href="/wiki/Adidas" title="Adidas">
       Adidas
      </a>
      , was named the
      <i>
       Jabulani
      </i>
      , which means
      <i>
       "bringing joy to everyone"
      </i>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Zulu_language" title="Zulu language">
       Zulu
      </a>
      . It was the eleventh World Cup match ball made by the German sports equipment maker; it featured eleven colours, representing each player of a team on the pitch and the eleven official
      <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_South_Africa" title="Languages of South Africa">
       languages of South Africa
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
       <a href="#cite_note-87">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        87
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
       <a href="#cite_note-88">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        88
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A special match ball with gold panels, called the
      <i>
       Jo'bulani
      </i>
      , was used at the final in
      <a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">
       Johannesburg
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      The ball was constructed using a new design, consisting of eight thermally bonded, three-dimensional panels. These were spherically moulded from
      <a href="/wiki/Ethylene-vinyl_acetate" title="Ethylene-vinyl acetate">
       ethylene-vinyl acetate
      </a>
      (EVA) and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thermoplastic_polyurethanes" title="Thermoplastic polyurethanes">
       thermoplastic polyurethanes
      </a>
      (TPU). The surface of the ball was textured with grooves, a technology developed by Adidas called GripnGroove
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
       <a href="#cite_note-89">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        89
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      that was intended to improve the ball's aerodynamics. The design received considerable academic input, being developed in partnership with researchers from
      <a href="/wiki/Loughborough_University" title="Loughborough University">
       Loughborough University
      </a>
      , United Kingdom.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
       <a href="#cite_note-90">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        90
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The balls were made in China, using latex bladders made in India, thermoplastic polyurethane-elastomer from Taiwan, ethylene vinyl acetate, isotropic polyester/cotton fabric, and glue and ink from China.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
       <a href="#cite_note-91">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        91
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Some football stars complained about the new ball, arguing that its movements were difficult to predict.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
       <a href="#cite_note-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Brazilian goalkeeper
      <a href="/wiki/J%C3%BAlio_C%C3%A9sar_(football_goalkeeper,_born_1979)" title="Jlio Csar (football goalkeeper, born 1979)">
       Jlio Csar
      </a>
      compared it to a "supermarket" ball that favored strikers and worked against goalkeepers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
       <a href="#cite_note-93">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        93
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Argentinian coach
      <a href="/wiki/Diego_Maradona" title="Diego Maradona">
       Diego Maradona
      </a>
      said: "We won't see any long passes in this World Cup because the ball doesn't fly straight."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
       <a href="#cite_note-94">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        94
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, a number of Adidas-sponsored
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
       <a href="#cite_note-95">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        95
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
       <a href="#cite_note-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
       <a href="#cite_note-97">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        97
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      players responded favourably to the ball.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Vuvuzelas">
       Vuvuzelas
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vuvuzela_blower,_Final_Draw,_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="533" data-file-width="800" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Vuvuzela_blower%2C_Final_Draw%2C_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg/220px-Vuvuzela_blower%2C_Final_Draw%2C_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Vuvuzela_blower%2C_Final_Draw%2C_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg/330px-Vuvuzela_blower%2C_Final_Draw%2C_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Vuvuzela_blower%2C_Final_Draw%2C_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg/440px-Vuvuzela_blower%2C_Final_Draw%2C_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vuvuzela_blower,_Final_Draw,_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A man sounding a vuvuzela
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Vuvuzela" title="Vuvuzela">
       Vuvuzela
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The 2010 finals amplified international public awareness of the
      <a href="/wiki/Vuvuzela" title="Vuvuzela">
       vuvuzela
      </a>
      , a long horn blown by fans throughout matches.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
       <a href="#cite_note-98">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        98
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
       <a href="#cite_note-99">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        99
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
       <a href="#cite_note-100">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        100
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
       <a href="#cite_note-101">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        101
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Many World Cup competitors complained about the noise caused by the vuvuzela horns, including France's
      <a href="/wiki/Patrice_Evra" title="Patrice Evra">
       Patrice Evra
      </a>
      , who blamed the horns for the team's poor performance.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbcponder_102-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-bbcponder-102">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        102
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other critics include
      <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Messi" title="Lionel Messi">
       Lionel Messi
      </a>
      , who complained that the sound of the vuvuzelas hampers communication among players on the pitch,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
       <a href="#cite_note-103">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        103
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and broadcasting companies, which complained that commentators' voices were being drowned out by the sound.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google1_104-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-google1-104">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        104
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Others watching on television complained that the ambient audio feed from the stadium only contains the sounds of the vuvuzelas and the natural sounds of people in the stands are drowned out.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyp1_105-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nyp1-105">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        105
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
       <a href="#cite_note-106">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        106
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A spokesperson for
      <a href="/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">
       ESPN
      </a>
      and other networks said that they were taking steps to minimise the ambient noise on their broadcasts.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
       <a href="#cite_note-107">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        107
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">
       BBC
      </a>
      also investigated the possibility of offering broadcasts without vuvuzela noise.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
       <a href="#cite_note-108">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        108
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Event_effects">
       Event effects
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy_Tour_Coca-Cola_aeroplane.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="576" data-file-width="1024" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy_Tour_Coca-Cola_aeroplane.jpg/220px-FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy_Tour_Coca-Cola_aeroplane.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy_Tour_Coca-Cola_aeroplane.jpg/330px-FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy_Tour_Coca-Cola_aeroplane.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy_Tour_Coca-Cola_aeroplane.jpg/440px-FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy_Tour_Coca-Cola_aeroplane.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy_Tour_Coca-Cola_aeroplane.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A FIFA World Cup Trophy Tour aeroplane, sponsored by
        <a href="/wiki/Coca-Cola" title="Coca-Cola">
         Coca-Cola
        </a>
        . (2010)
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_event_effects" title="2010 FIFA World Cup event effects">
       2010 FIFA World Cup event effects
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Social">
       Social
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Tournament organiser
      <a href="/wiki/Danny_Jordaan" title="Danny Jordaan">
       Danny Jordaan
      </a>
      dismissed concerns that the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Togo_national_football_team_bus_attack" title="Togo national football team bus attack">
       attack on the Togo national team
      </a>
      which took place in
      <a href="/wiki/Angola" title="Angola">
       Angola
      </a>
      in January 2010, had any relevance to the security arrangements for the World Cup.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCSport09Jan2010JordaanTogo_109-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BBCSport09Jan2010JordaanTogo-109">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        109
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      There were also reports of thefts against visitors to the country for the World Cup. Tourists from China, Portugal, Spain, South Korea, Japan and
      <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">
       Colombia
      </a>
      had become victims of crime.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
       <a href="#cite_note-110">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        110
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      On 19 June after the match between England and Algeria a fan was able to break through the FIFA-appointed security staff at Green Point stadium and gain access to the England team dressing room. The breach took place shortly after
      <a href="/wiki/Prince_William,_Duke_of_Cambridge" title="Prince William, Duke of Cambridge">
       Prince William
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Prince_Harry" title="Prince Harry">
       Prince Harry
      </a>
      had left the room. The trespasser was then released before he could be handed over to the Police.
      <a href="/wiki/The_Football_Association" title="The Football Association">
       English FA
      </a>
      lodged a formal complaint with FIFA and demanded that security be increased.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
       <a href="#cite_note-111">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        111
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Resettlement_and_eviction">
       Resettlement and eviction
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="750" data-file-width="1000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG/220px-2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG/330px-2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG/440px-2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Police patrol Blikkiesdorp, a settlement for the evicted.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      As with many 'hallmark events' throughout the world,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
       <a href="#cite_note-112">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        112
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      the 2010 FIFA World Cup has been connected to
      <a href="/wiki/Eviction" title="Eviction">
       evictions
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
       <a href="#cite_note-113">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        113
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
       <a href="#cite_note-114">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        114
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
       <a href="#cite_note-115">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        115
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
       <a href="#cite_note-116">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        116
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newsweek1_117-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-newsweek1-117">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        117
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      which many claim are meant to 'beautify the city', impress visiting tourists, and hide shackdwellers. On 14 May 2009, the Durban-based shack-dwellers' movement
      <a href="/wiki/Abahlali_baseMjondolo" title="Abahlali baseMjondolo">
       Abahlali baseMjondolo
      </a>
      took the KwaZulu-Natal government to court over their controversial
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Elimination_and_Prevention_of_Re-Emergence_of_Slums_Act" title="Elimination and Prevention of Re-Emergence of Slums Act">
       Elimination and Prevention of Re-Emergence of Slums Act
      </a>
      , meant to eliminate slums in South Africa and put homeless shackdwellers in transit camps in time for the 2010 World Cup.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
       <a href="#cite_note-118">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        118
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
       <a href="#cite_note-119">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        119
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Another prominent controversy surrounding preparations for the World Cup was the
      <a href="/wiki/N2_Gateway" title="N2 Gateway">
       N2 Gateway
      </a>
      housing project in
      <a href="/wiki/Cape_Town" title="Cape Town">
       Cape Town
      </a>
      , which planned to remove over 20,000 residents from the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joe_Slovo_Informal_Settlement" title="Joe Slovo Informal Settlement">
       Joe Slovo Informal Settlement
      </a>
      along the busy N2 Freeway and build rental flats and bond-houses in its place in time for the 2010 World Cup.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
       <a href="#cite_note-120">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        120
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      NGOs, international human rights organisations, and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-Eviction_Campaign" title="Anti-Eviction Campaign">
       Anti-Eviction Campaign
      </a>
      have publicly criticised the conditions in
      <a href="/wiki/Blikkiesdorp" title="Blikkiesdorp">
       Blikkiesdorp
      </a>
      and said that the camp has been used to accommodate poor families evicted to make way for the 2010 World Cup.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newsweek1_117-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-newsweek1-117">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        117
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Smith_121-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Smith-121">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        121
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
       <a href="#cite_note-122">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        122
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
       <a href="#cite_note-123">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        123
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      However some have argued that evictions are ordinarily common in South Africa and that in the lead up to the tournament many evictions were erreonously ascribed to the World Cup.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
       <a href="#cite_note-124">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        124
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
       Economy
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Some groups experienced complications in regards to scheduled sporting events, advertising, or broadcasting, as FIFA attempted to maximise control of media rights during the Cup. Affected parties included an international
      <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">
       rugby union
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Test_match_(rugby_union)" title="Test match (rugby union)">
       Test match
      </a>
      , a South African airline, and some TV networks, all of whom were involved in various legal struggles with World Cup organisers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
       <a href="#cite_note-125">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        125
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kulula_126-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Kulula-126">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        126
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
       <a href="#cite_note-127">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        127
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      During the tournament, group ticket-holders who did not utilise all their allotted tickets led to some early-round matches having as many as 11,000 unoccupied seats.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
       <a href="#cite_note-128">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        128
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      While the event did help to boost the image of South Africa, financially it turned out to be a major disappointment.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tele_129-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-tele-129">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        129
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Construction costs for venues and infrastructure amounted to 3billion (3.6billion), and the government expected that increased tourism would help to offset these costs to the amount of 570million (680million). However, only 323million (385million) were actually taken in as 309,000 foreign fans came to South Africa, well below the expected number of 450,000.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tele_129-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-tele-129">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        129
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Local vendors were prohibited from selling food and merchandise within a 1.5kilometre radius of any stadium hosting a World Cup match. For a vendor to operate within the radius, a registration fee of
      <a href="/wiki/South_African_rand" title="South African rand">
       R
      </a>
      60,000 (approximately to US$7,888 or 6,200), had to be paid to
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">
       FIFA
      </a>
      . This fee was out of most local vendors' reach, as they are simple one-man-operated vendors. This prevented international visitors from experiencing local South African food. Some local vendors felt cheated out of an opportunity for financial gain and spreading South African culture, in favour of multinational corporations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
       <a href="#cite_note-130">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        130
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      FIFA president Sepp Blatter declared the event "a huge financial success for everybody, for Africa, for South Africa and for FIFA," with revenue to FIFA of 2.24billion (2billion).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
       <a href="#cite_note-131">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        131
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Quality">
       Quality
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In a December 2010
      <i>
       Quality Progress
      </i>
      , FIFA President Blatter rated South Africa's organisational efforts a nine out of 10 scale, declaring that South Africa could be considered a plan B for all future competitions. The South African Quality Institute (SAQI) assisted in facility construction, event promotion, and organisations. The main issue listed in the article was transportation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
       <a href="#cite_note-132">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        132
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
       Media
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Broadcasting">
       Broadcasting
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_broadcasting_rights" title="2010 FIFA World Cup broadcasting rights">
       2010 FIFA World Cup broadcasting rights
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg/220px-Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg/330px-Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg/440px-Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Production set of the FIFA international broadcast centre during the event
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The 2010 FIFA World Cup was expected to be the most-watched television event in history.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UT_133-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UT-133">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        133
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Hundreds of broadcasters, representing about 70 countries, transmitted the Cup to a TV audience that FIFA officials expect to exceed a cumulative 26billion people, an average of approximately 400million viewers per match. FIFA estimated that around 700 million viewers would watch the
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Final" title="2010 FIFA World Cup Final">
       World Cup final
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fifaestimate_134-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-fifaestimate-134">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        134
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      New forms of digital media have also allowed viewers to watch coverage through alternative means. "With games airing live on cell phones and computers, the World Cup will get more online coverage than any major sporting event yet," said Jake Coyle of the
      <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">
       Associated Press
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coyle_135-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Coyle-135">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        135
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the United States,
      <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">
       ABC
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">
       ESPN
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/ESPN2" title="ESPN2">
       ESPN2
      </a>
      averaged a 2.1 rating, 2,288,000 households and 3,261,000 viewers for the 64 World Cup games. The rating was up 31 percent from a 1.6 in 2006, while households increased 32 percent from 1,735,000 and viewers rose from 2,316,000. The increases had been higher while the US remained in the tournament. Through the first 50 games, the rating was up 48 percent, households increased 54 percent and viewers rose 60 percent.
      <a href="/wiki/Univision" title="Univision">
       Univision
      </a>
      averaged 2,624,000 viewers for the tournament, up 17 percent, and 1,625,000 households, an increase of 11 percent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
       <a href="#cite_note-136">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        136
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      An executive of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nielsen_Company" title="Nielsen Company">
       Nielsen Company
      </a>
      , a leading audience research firm in the US, described the aggregate numbers for both networks' coverage of the USA-Ghana match as "phenomenal".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
       <a href="#cite_note-137">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        137
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Live World Cup streaming on
      <a href="/wiki/ESPN3" title="ESPN3">
       ESPN3.com
      </a>
      pulled in some of the largest audiences in history, as 7.4 million unique viewers tuned in for matches. In total, ESPN3.com generated 942 million minutes of viewing or more than two hours per unique viewer. All 64 live matches were viewed by an average of 114,000 persons per minute. Most impressive were the numbers for the semi-final between Spain and Germany, which was viewed by 355,000 people per minute, making it ESPN3.com's largest average audience ever.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
       <a href="#cite_note-138">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        138
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Filming">
       Filming
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Sony technology was used to film the tournament. 25 of the matches were captured using 3D cameras.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
       <a href="#cite_note-139">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        139
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Footage was captured in 3D through Sony's proprietary multi-image MPE-200 processors, housed in specially designed 3D outside broadcast trucks.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
       <a href="#cite_note-140">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        140
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It supplied its flagship HDC-1500 cameras as well as its new HDC-P1 unit, a compact, point-of-view (POV)-type camera with 3, 2/3-inch CCD sensors.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
       <a href="#cite_note-141">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        141
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The 3D games were produced for FIFA by Host Broadcast Services.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
       <a href="#cite_note-142">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        142
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Video_games">
       Video games
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In
      <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_Home" title="PlayStation Home">
       PlayStation Home
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Sony" title="Sony">
       Sony
      </a>
      has released a
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_PlayStation_Home_Game_Spaces#Non-gaming_Company_Spaces" title="List of PlayStation Home Game Spaces">
       virtual space
      </a>
      based on the 2010 FIFA World Cup in the Japanese version of Home on 3 December 2009. This virtual space is called the "FevaArena" and is a virtual stadium of the 2010 FIFA World Cup, featuring different areas for events, a FIFA mini-game, and a shop with FIFA related content.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
       <a href="#cite_note-143">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        143
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On 27 April 2010,
      <a href="/wiki/EA_Sports" title="EA Sports">
       EA Sports
      </a>
      released the official
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_South_Africa_(video_game)" title="2010 FIFA World Cup South Africa (video game)">
       2010 World Cup video game
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
       <a href="#cite_note-144">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        144
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="FIFA_Fan_Fest">
       FIFA Fan Fest
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      FIFA expanded the
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA_Fan_Fest" title="FIFA Fan Fest">
       FIFA Fan Fest
      </a>
      , hosting in
      <a href="/wiki/Sydney" title="Sydney">
       Sydney
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">
       Buenos Aires
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">
       Berlin
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">
       Paris
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">
       Rome
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(city)" title="Rio de Janeiro (city)">
       Rio de Janeiro
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">
       Mexico City
      </a>
      , as well as several venues around South Africa.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
       <a href="#cite_note-145">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        145
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Durban Fan Fest was the most popular in South Africa during the tournament followed by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Cup_2010_FIFA_Fan_Fest_in_Cape_Town" title="World Cup 2010 FIFA Fan Fest in Cape Town">
       Cape Town Fan Fest
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
       <a href="#cite_note-146">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        146
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
       See also
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="noprint portal tright" style="border:solid #aaa 1px;margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em">

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="padding:0 0.2em;vertical-align:middle;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold">

         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr style="vertical-align:middle">
        <td style="text-align:center">

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="padding:0 0.2em;vertical-align:middle;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold">
